title: Little Maria Mountains
text:
The Little Maria Mountains are located in southeastern <a href="California">California</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. The range lies in a northwest-southeasterly direction east of the <a href="Palen%20Mountains">Palen Mountains</a> and west of the <a href="Big%20Maria%20Mountains">Big Maria Mountains</a>. The mountain range is approximately 15 miles long and is located about 12.6 miles north of <a href="Interstate%2010%20%28California%29">Interstate 10</a>, and 12 miles southwest of the abandoned Rice Army Airfield near <a href="California%20State%20Route%2062">State Route 62</a>. The Victor Mine is found at the southeastern end of the range near <a href="Midland%2C%20California">Midland</a>.
Geology.
The Little Maria Mountains are one of several ranges that constitute the <a href="Maria%20Fold%20and%20Thrust%20Belt">Maria Fold and Thrust Belt</a>. The Maria Fold and Thrust Belt underwent generally <a href="Thick-skinned%20deformation">thick-skinned</a> (involving <a href="basement%20rocks">basement rocks</a>) North-South trending crustal shortening in the <a href="Cretaceous">Cretaceous</a>. The structures of the MFTB are exposed by to later generally East-West trending large-scale crustal extension in the <a href="Miocene">Miocene</a>, through what is known to geologists as the <a href="Colorado%20River%20Extensional%20Corridor">Colorado River Extensional Corridor</a>. This North-South shortening is anomalous, as crustal shortening in the rest of the <a href="North%20American%20Cordillera">North American Cordillera</a> is oriented generally East-West because of the generally East-West compression that was due to the subduction of the <a href="Farallon%20plate">Farallon plate</a> under western North America. Also unlike the rest of the North American Cordillera, deformation in the Maria Fold and Thrust Belt involved rocks of the <a href="North%20American%20Craton">North American Craton</a>, most notably the <a href="Geology%20of%20the%20Grand%20Canyon%20area">Grand Canyon sequence</a> of sedimentary rocks.
Palen/McCoy Wilderness Area.
The Little Maria Mountains are in the <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20140422033106/http%3A//www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/fo/palmsprings/wilderness/palen-mccoy.html">Palen/McCoy Wilderness Area</a>, managed by the <a href="Bureau%20of%20Land%20Management">Bureau of Land Management</a>.
Within the Palen-McCoy Wilderness are the Little Maria, Granite, <a href="Arica%20Mountains">Arica</a>, <a href="Palen%20Mountains">Palen</a>, and <a href="McCoy%20Mountains">McCoy Mountains</a>, which are five distinct mountain ranges separated by broad sloping <a href="Alluvial%20fan">Alluvial fan</a>s-bajadas. Because this large area incorporates so many major geological features, the diversity of vegetation and <a href="landform">landform</a>s is exceptional. The desert wash woodland found here provides food and cover for <a href="Mule%20deer">burro deer</a>, coyote, <a href="bobcat">bobcat</a>, gray fox, and <a href="mountain%20lion">mountain lion</a>. <a href="Desert%20pavement">Desert pavement</a>, bajadas, interior valleys, canyons, dense ironwood forests-("<a href="Olneya%20tesota">Olneya tesota</a>"), canyons, and rugged peaks, form a constantly changing landscape pattern.
